name: Portland
fun_fact: Fun fact: Portland's iconic Stumptown Coffee got its name from the mid-19th century when the city grew so fast that tree stumps from clearing land were left in the middle of roads. The original Stumptown location was previously a hair salon called 'The Hair Bender' - a name they adopted for their signature espresso blend, which became world-famous.

hero_dishes.name: Marionberry Pie
hero_dishes.description: Oregon's official state pie featuring the sweetly tangy deep violet marionberry - a blackberry cultivar created at Oregon State University
hero_dishes.origin_story: The marionberry was developed specifically in Oregon and has become a symbol of Pacific Northwest pride. It's only available seasonally, making it a treasured summer treat
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lauretta Jean's is famous for their marionberry pie (seasonal availability only)

hero_dishes.name: Khao Man Gai
hero_dishes.description: Thai poached chicken with fragrant rice, served with an intensely flavorful ginger-garlic sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Nong's Khao Man Gai started as a humble food cart and became a Portland legend. The dish is deceptively simple but powerfully flavored - representing Portland's food cart culture at its finest
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Nong's Khao Man Gai, evolved from food cart to brick-and-mortar success story

hero_dishes.name: Jojo Potatoes
hero_dishes.description: Seasoned potato wedges that were invented in the Pacific Northwest - crispy outside, fluffy inside, often served with ranch or fry sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in the Northwest and remaining a beloved Portland snack that locals grew up with. The name origin is debated but the love is universal
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Reel M Inn and Jojo are especially known for their jojos

hero_dishes.name: White Curry with Brisket Burnt Ends (Eem)
hero_dishes.description: Thai white curry infused with Texas BBQ brisket burnt ends - a fusion that shouldn't work but absolutely does
hero_dishes.origin_story: Eem on North Williams Avenue was named 2019 Restaurant of the Year by The Oregonian. Their Thai-Texas BBQ fusion represents Portland's fearless culinary creativity
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Eem on North Williams Avenue - the white curry with brisket burnt ends is the must-order

hero_dishes.name: Filipino Feast at Magna Kusina
hero_dishes.description: Charcoal-grilled skewers, longanisa sausage, garlicky laing (coconut-braised taro greens), and legendary lumpia
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chef Carlo Lamagna serves Portland's most polished Filipino food, with dishes that skew traditional but executed with precision
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Magna Kusina - showcasing Filipino cuisine's place in Portland's diverse food scene

hero_dishes.name: Jipbap Feast at Han Oak
hero_dishes.description: Korean home cooking remixed with Oregon ingredients - $65 multi-course feast served with house party vibes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Han Oak operates on its own terms, blending Korean culture, Oregon ingredients, and cheeky flavor notes in a magical indoor-outdoor space
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Han Oak - reservation required for the jipbap feast experience

signature_drinks.name: Stumptown Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Third-wave craft coffee roasted in Portland since 1999, with signature blends like Hair Bender espresso
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Portland takes coffee seriously - Stumptown pioneered paying farmers 3-4 times fair trade prices and treating coffee as an artisanal product. Locals drink it black to taste the single-origin beans or as precisely crafted lattes. Stumptown also pioneered nitro cold brew in cans

signature_drinks.name: Craft Beer (Beervana)
signature_drinks.description: Portland has been called 'Beervana' with legendary breweries like Baerlic, Gigantic, McMenamins, Occidental, and Wayfinder
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Beer culture dates to the mid-1800s with Henry Weinhard's City Brewery. The first brewpubs opened in 1984 and sparked a movement. Locals support neighborhood breweries and seek out unique, locally brewed beers

signature_drinks.name: Steven Smith Teamaker Tea
signature_drinks.description: High-quality small-batch teas from a Portland company founded in 2009 (Portland also birthed Stash and Tazo)
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: While Portland is famous for coffee, it's also a tea city - Steven Smith focuses on small-batch quality sourced globally

signature_drinks.name: Creative Cafe Drinks
signature_drinks.description: Innovative drinks like Never Coffee Lab's 'Rich Kid' (rose water, saffron, cardamom) or the 'Oregon' (dulce de leche, Jacobsen sea salt, Cascade hops)
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Portland's creative spirit extends to cafe drinks, blending local ingredients like sea salt and hops into coffee beverages

500+ food carts create legendary street food scene - sample Korean-Mexican fusion to Ethiopian to vegan bento for under $15
Farm-to-table movement thrives with fresh Pacific Northwest seasonal ingredients
Abundant plant-based restaurant options pioneered here
The Jade District showcases Chinese cuisine and Asian immigrant entrepreneurship
Portland Mercado is a hub of Latine culture and entrepreneurship through food
